title: The Role of Hormone Replacement Therapy in Women's Health
content: Avrum Bluming and Carol Tavris discuss their book, Estrogen Matters, which takes on the topic of hormone replacement therapy for women suffering with symptoms of menopause. They make a compelling case that most women benefit greatly from being on postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy, and can do so without increasing their risk of breast cancer. They also cover the history of HRT, the impact of the Women’s Health Initiative, and take a deep dive into each of the clinical conditions for which HRT should be considered, such as cardiovascular disease and neurodegenerative disease, and osteoporosis, to name a few.

title: Dispelling the Myth that HRT Causes Breast Cancer
content: Avrum Bluming and Carol Tavris dispel the myth that hormone replacement therapy causes breast cancer. They make a compelling case that most women benefit greatly from being on postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy, and can do so without increasing their risk of breast cancer.

title: The Background of Estrogen Matters
content: Dr. Carol Tavris, a social psychologist, and Dr. Avrum Bluming, a medical oncologist, wrote Estrogen Matters to bring good scientific research in psychology and medicine to public attention. Dr. Tavris has always been interested in the barriers to critical thinking and the reasons that people do not accept information when it is in their best interest to do so. Dr. Bluming has spent over 50 years as a medical oncologist and has watched the progress in breast cancer very happily noting how many people we now cure.

title: The Issue with Breast Cancer Treatment
content: While Dr. Bluming was making a lot of people better in terms of the cancer, he was making them worse in terms of the symptoms associated with the treatments they got. The major assumption dealing with breast cancer is that estrogen causes breast cancer, and it doesn’t. Almost everything we’ve done in the treatment of breast cancer is based on that assumption so that women have been denied estrogen for at least the last 30 years. . . and the result is that many women have been hurt by being denied that medicine.

title: The sad early history of hormone replacement therapy
content: Carol and Avrum’s 2009 paper, Hormone Replacement Therapy: Real Concerns and False Alarms, has a beautiful time course of hormone replacement therapy in women: Figure 2. HRT and Breast Cancer: A timeline of relevant events and studies. Image credit: (Bluming and Tavris, 2009). Men vs. Women: Comparing the early history of hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Using the example of how we treated prostate cancer in men with breast cancer in women… The number of women with breast cancer and men with prostate cancer is approximately comparable in the United States. And the number of women who die of breast cancer is comparable to the number of men who die of prostate cancer each year. Therefore, the medical establishment made the false leap that testosterone is responsible for prostate cancer and estrogen is therefore responsible for breast cancer. Prostate cancer was treated initially by castration of the testicle ⇒ it doesn’t cure it, but it helps in some cases. So, women were castrated by removal of the ovaries to eliminate estrogen to treat breast cancer ⇒ it helps in some cases, but not many. For prostate cancer, if the castration didn’t work, we stopped and gave palliative care. With breast cancer, if castration didn’t help, we kept removing things… Adrenal glands of women (by the way, adrenal glands make a small percentages of circulating testosterone, but we never removed the adrenal glands of men). Once you remove the adrenal gland, you have to replace the hormones that were necessary for survival, which they did. If the adrenal gland removal didn’t work, we then would take out the anterior pituitary gland at the base of the brain because that gland produces a hormone that stimulates either the ovary or the testicle to make the responsible hormone. We used to do hypophysectomies and while I was in practice, we did that, says Avrum. But again, the anterior pituitary makes many hormones that are necessary for survival so they had to replace many of those hormones. They even started to prophylactically remove the ovaries of those who previously had breast cancer to try to keep it from coming back. And even after all of this, “we didn’t really help too many women with that”. “Let me reiterate, we did nothing like that for men and we hurt a lot of women by doing that. We did it with good intentions, but we hurt them.” Early history of HRT using estrogen. A book in 1968 called Feminine Forever by Robert A. Wilson. The book essentially said women should take estrogen forever and it’ll be an eternal fountain of youth. But that’s not true, that book was oversold, and the doctor who wrote that book was paid for by the drug company who made estrogen. This book did a lot of damage to the trust of community in terms of using estrogen as a treatment. But estrogen did do some very good things… ⇒ First, estrogen can relieve the symptoms of menopause. And it’s not just hot flashes and night sweats, symptoms include: Palpitations cognitive decline joint pains sleep disturbances depression. “It usually lasts about seven and a half years, not two years, and in some women it goes on for decades and women are taught to suck it up and deal with that.” Estrogen and heart disease. In 1991, an article was published: Uncertainty about Postmenopausal Estrogen — Time for Action, Not Debate. It suggested that estrogen is also capable of reducing significant heart disease by up to 50%. “That was 1991 and we now know that estrogen has been shown repeatedly to help diminish the risk for significant heart conditions.”

title: What hormones do, and why they drop off rapidly in women compared to gradually in men
content: Peter hardly ever prints a physical copy of a paper, however, these two are a couple of the exceptions: First publication of the WHI and the 2003 republication. A figure showing the hormone cycle for a woman during her reproductive years… “I started doing this about three years ago and I was surprised how many women didn’t know what estrogen was doing in their body.” Figure 3. Hormone cycle. Image credit: primaleye.uk

title: Hormonal Changes in Women
content: It has to do with the reduction of progesterone. And in some women, the fall of progesterone during the end of the luteal phase is so rapid (for reasons we don’t understand) it produces a drastic change. Female hormones rapidly decline (not gradual). Women have hormones such as luteinizing hormone, follicle stimulating hormone and they are coming out of the pituitary and telling the ovaries to make yet more hormones. Then suddenly, during menopause, their production seem to drop off a cliff. Why? ⇒ Evolution may have wanted women to be able to reproduce up to a point and then it turns off the hormones that are responsible for allowing reproduction (i.e. this cycle of rising estrogen, progesterone falling). This is a crucial thing to say, Peter. This is really important. I assumed that in menopause, estrogen declines. I think that’s the way women see it. It just declines the way testosterone declines in a slow, moderate way. No, estrogen plummets to 1% of what it was before menopause. I think most women have no idea that it’s that great a drop in estrogen levels and no wonder that many of the symptoms that women have, which by the way include depression which they’ve attributed to a ‘midlife crisis’. No, it could be an estrogen depletion crisis as well. I think it’s really important for women to understand that this is not just as a little fall off, it’s really a major drop.

title: Mistreatment of Women in Medicine
content: What interests me is the way women have been given false information for so many years about so many aspects of their reproductive cycle and experience that it’s no wonder that many women have a great skepticism about what medicine has to offer them in reproductive issues. There was so little hesitation in cutting women up, removing this part and removing that part, things that would never have been tried with men. Feminine Forever by Robert Wilson oversold the benefits of estrogen. Robert Wilson was paid by makers of estrogen treatments to write the book. It created even further skepticism. It also created a defiance in the feminist community of “the hell with all of you on this estrogen, I don’t need it, it doesn’t make me feminine forever and who dares to think that I need to be feminine forever in that traditional way!” The routine use of hysterectomy on the assumption that a woman, once she’s had her children, doesn’t need to have her uterus. And by the way, since we’re removing your uterus, let’s remove your ovaries as well because what the hell, they’re just there, let’s take them out as if they have no function. That casual attitude of let’s just get in there and get rid of.

title: Breast Cancer vs Heart Disease in Women
content: Estrogen can significantly decrease the risk of heart disease. However, many women believe that “old women die of heart disease, young women die of breast cancer”. So the women often say they’d rather not take estrogen if estrogen causes breast cancer. First of all, estrogen does not cause breast cancer. But more than that, in every decade of a woman’s life, the incidence of death from heart disease is greater than the incidence of death from breast cancer. Heart disease kills more women than the next 16 causes of death, including all forms of cancer, AIDS and accidents.

title: Mortality from Breast Cancer and Cardiovascular Disease
content: Risk of dying (US): 1-in-4 (25%) women die of heart disease. The lifetime risk of dying from breast cancer is 1-in-38 (2.6%). In other words, women are 10 times more likely to die from heart disease than breast cancer. Risk of developing (US): Women have a 1-in-8 (12%) risk of getting breast cancer. The lifetime risk for cardiovascular disease is more than 1 in 2. In other words, women are ~5 times more likely to get heart disease than breast cancer.

title: Symptoms of Heart Disease in Women
content: Almost two-thirds (64%) of women who die suddenly of coronary heart disease have no previous symptoms. Women present with heart disease quite differently than men. Men tend to have crushing chest pain that radiates down their left arm, starting at the shoulder. Women, however, can often present with an upset stomach. And because we generally don’t think of women as suffering from heart disease, the diagnosis is initially missed quite often.

title: Symptoms of Menopause
content: Case studies of women suffering symptoms of menopause [30:00]. Peter was caring for a female patient. Unexpected symptoms. Many of the symptoms that women begin to develop in their 40s, they don’t associate with menopause. Muscle pain sends them to rheumatologists and depression sends them to therapists and fighting with their spouses sends them to family therapy. And they don’t think that their changes of menopause might be involved.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: Avrum: No vested interest, either. However, he does have a personal story to share… His wife got breast cancer at age 45. She was treated with chemotherapy and at the same time she went into menopause. She was very symptomatic (although, she didn’t complain for two years). Night sweats, difficulty sleeping, joint pains, Palpitations. She eventually was put on HRT ⇒ “It took about two weeks and she was back. She would never go off them.”

title: HRT and Breast Cancer Risk
content: She couldn’t find any doctor on the planet who would prescribe hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to her, because as a breast cancer survivor who’s ER/PR-positive, how could you do such a thing? Though she did eventually find someone who was willing to give her a trial. Her case interested me so much, because I started thinking, ‘Wait a minute. Isn’t she increasing her risk of breast cancer?’ I won’t get into the details of where that took me, which rabbit hole, but it obviously in some way led to a converging discussion that we’re having today.”

title: History of HRT
content: Robert Wilson’s book, Feminine Forever, has encouraged many women to get on estrogen. Premarin, acronym for pregnant mare urine, is still the most used form of estrogen today. In the early 1970s, there was a sharp rise in uterine cancer. Turns out, estrogen, given alone, can increase uterine cancer by 5-fold, says Avrum. In the late 1970s, it was learned that progesterone together with estrogen, nullified the risk of uterine cancer, so HRT started to increase again. By 2004, HRT use was down from 22% to 10% of age appropriate population. By 2010, HRT use fell to 5%. This was largely due to the first publication of the Women’s Health Initiative.

title: Women's Health Initiative
content: The theoretical rationale for the study was NOT to see whether it increased breast cancer… what they wanted to see is did it really have a beneficial effect on the heart and the brain and the bones. The WHI had two separate studies: 1) Nutritional study 2) Hormone replacement study. Problems with the hormone replacement arm of the WHI: The study participants: Avg age was 63 (which is 10 years after menopause). 70% were very overweight or obese. >50% were smokers. Many had hypertension. This was not an ideal, healthy sample, by any means. For economic reasons, it made sense to choose an older population. But this was never a normal population, and as soon as the study came out in 2002, it was immediately extrapolated to all women everywhere. Exclusion of symptomatic women.

title: HRT and Breast Cancer Risk
content: The WHI reported “findings” that HRT had absolutely no benefit on quality of life. The reason they found that is because women who were significantly symptomatic were excluded. By the way, the 13% of the women who were symptomatic had a significant improvement, but they were lost among the entire population. Additionally, the alleged increased risk of breast cancer was not statistically significant.

title: WHI Press Release
content: Prior to the release of the actual data… The WHI put out a huge press release: Clinical Alert: NHLBI Stops Trial of Estrogen Plus Progestin Due to Increased Breast Cancer Risk, Lack of Overall Benefit. This is a big no-no in scientific communication and publication. The alleged increased risk of breast cancer was not statistically significant. It is unprecedented that a press release would be put out prior to the study with the data.

title: The pressure to come up with a significant finding
content: Rowan Chlebowski, one of the 3 writers of the WHI publication, said the following (paraphrase): “You know, this is the most expensive study ever done. By the time we’re finished, it will cost about a billion dollars. So, if we think we have found something and the results don’t quite add up, the statistical police have to leave the room.” Garnet Anderson, the statistician for the WHI, said the following (paraphrase): “Well, when it’s an issue as important to women as breast cancer, we intentionally set the bar low.”

title: Why people (falsely) think estrogen causes a 25% increase in breast cancer
content: A very common question Peter gets from women: Doesn’t HRT increase the risk of breast cancer by 25%? 2013 JAMA paper: Menopausal Hormone Therapy and Health Outcomes During the Intervention and Extended Poststopping Phases of the Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Trials (Manson et al., 2013) 2015 JAMA paper: Breast Cancer After Use of Estrogen Plus Progestin and Estrogen Alone, Analyses of Data From 2 Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Clinical Trials (Chlebowski, et al., 2015)

title: Randomization of the study
content: Cohort #1: You had women who had already undergone a hysterectomy and they were randomized to estrogen (CEE, conjugated equine estrogen) or placebo Cohort #2: And women whose uterus was still in place were randomized to CEE plus MPA (medroxyprogesterone acetate) versus a placebo

title: Results of the study
content: The women in cohort 1, those that were randomized to just estrogen, had no increased risk of breast cancer. They actually had a 21% decreased risk, but it was not statistically significant. The women in cohort 2, those that received both estrogen and progesterone, there was a reported 26% increase in risk of breast cancer compared to placebo. However, it also wasn’t statistically significant… “So by scientific standards, we think that could have been caused by chance alone.” P-value was below .05

title: Absolute vs. Relative risk
content: Additionally, the 26% increase was the “relative” increase. The absolute increase in risk was 0.9 cases per 1,000, that’s 9 cases per 10,000.

title: Absolute vs Relative Risk
content: That is a less than 1% absolute risk increase even it the 26% increase was shown to be significant (which is wasn’t) Another example of absolute vs relative risk: “Let’s say that eating a grapefruit doubles my risk of bunions. I need to know what numbers we’re talking about. If the numbers jumped from one person to two persons out of a hundred or out of a thousand, that’s not a very big thing. Let’s say it’s doubling the risk, but it’s trivial. If the numbers double from 500 to 1000 in a group of 10,000, then we might have a finding we should be paying attention to.” The lack of reported absolute risk: Carol laments, “Avrum and I were at pains in our book to see when we would read studies that reported an increase risk or reduced risk of something to see what the absolute number were. In many cases, we couldn’t even find what the absolute numbers were.”

title: Progesterone and Cancer Risk
content: What about progesterone (MPA)? Does is play a role in the increase in breast cancer? ⇒ Peter prefaces the question with the fact that when looking at WHI data, the women you got both progesterone and estrogen had an increased risk in breast cancer compared to those that just got estrogen Avrum: “First, let me go back to saying that the increased risks seen with the combination was not statistically significant, did not hold up, and was due largely a problem with the control group. If you accept that, anything that we say at this point is irrelevant. . .but I’ll take your question.” “What has resulted from that is people are saying, ‘Well, the problem really isn’t estrogen. We’ll give estrogen a pass. The problem is progesterone.’” In fact, this particular synthetic progesterone (MPA, medroxyprogesterone acetate) is being blamed “Well, I’m not sure there’s a problem because the numbers don’t really bear that out. If there is a problem, there are now forms of progesterone, which are not synthetic, that are now being advised and used; and thus far, have not been associated even with any finding of an increased risk of breast cancer.”

title: Progesterone as a Treatment for Breast Cancer
content: 1 In a randomized trial comparing tamoxifen to progesterone in the 1970s, progesterone did a little better than tamoxifen, but because in the dosage used, it was associated with increase fluid retention, and women became nauseated, it lost out to tamoxifen, but it was used to treat breast cancer. 2 There was a study that came out of India that found that giving an injection of progesterone around the time of surgery to remove primary breast cancer, significantly improved the prognosis, and decreased the risk of recurrence.

title: Are “Bioidentical” Hormones Better?
content: ⇒ Estrogen: “The word bioidentical is a buzzword.” says Avrum Bioidentical really refers to estradiol, which is the leading circulating estrogen in a woman’s body Bioidentical is also used for what is prepared by pharmacists based on prescriptions written by local practitioners where quality control is lacking. “There is no clear dose equivalency. Every responsible investigator I know wants to make the point that buying something because it’s got the word bioidentical, which sounds comforting, is a mistake.” Premarin (the most common estrogen medication) is an acronym for pregnant mare urine It is the longest studied form of estrogen. We, now, have 60 years of data with Premarin. Most of the studies that show the benefit for estrogen are studies that were done on Premarin Premarin contains at least 10 different forms of estrogen, including some that are the most beneficial forms of estrogen for brain health, which is not present in “bioidentical forms” such as estradiol or estriol. “My preference is Premarin because we have the most data supporting it.” says Avrum ⇒ Progesterone: “As far as progesterone is concerned, micronized bioidentical progesterone appears to be the safest form of progesterone administration.”

title: Estrogen and Breast Cancer
content: The blanket assumption is that estrogen causes breast cancer. However, to the contrary, as women get older and have lower estrogen levels, the rates of breast cancer increase.

title: The Women's Health Initiative
content: The Women’s Health Initiative reported findings that the combination of estrogen and progesterone increases the risk of breast cancer, increases the risk of heart attacks, increases the risk of cognitive decline, decreases the risk of colon cancer, and helps protect the bones. However, a follow-up article in 2006 said that the reported increased risk in that population had disappeared with continued follow up. JoAnn Manson is trying to course correct and the smallest dose for the least amount of time is now the mantra from the WHI investigators.

title: Benefits of HRT
content: Studies have shown that hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can increase the median survival of women by 3.3 years in the United States. There’s no other intervention that has such a great consequence for longevity. However, tens of thousands of women died prematurely as a result of being taken off hormone therapy.

title: Estrogen and Alzheimer's Disease
content: Women are two times more likely to die of Alzheimer’s disease than men. The reason is not that women live longer than men. Peter’s hypothesis is that it has to do with the fact that women have an abrupt loss of hormones whereas men have a gradual loss of hormones. Estrogen can reduce the incidence of Alzheimer’s disease by between 20 and 50% depending upon the study you look at.

title: The benefits of estrogen on the brain
content: The findings converge from all of those directions of research to show the benefits of estrogen on the brain. Barbara Sherwin, a psychologist at McGill University answer it this way, “I get so crossed when people say taking HRT is not natural. What’s not natural is for a woman to live to be 85 or 90 years old. And if estrogen is something that can help women to live with healthy mental functioning in those later years, then I am all for it.” Peter agrees: “If we’ve decided to live a society where we value living beyond our reproductive years, then why aren’t we entertaining things that are ‘unnatural’? It really is an asinine argument to me.”

title: The impact of HRT on heart disease
content: The report from the 2002 WHI suggested HRT increased risk of heart disease. Problems with the WHI study: 1 The study population was not cardiovascularly healthy. 2 Estrogen is capable of causing platelet clumping. If you already have blood vessels that are narrowed by preexisting heart disease, a platelet clumps can further narrow the blood vessel and caused a cardiac event. As a result of that, it is recommended that women with preexisting cardiovascular disease not start on hormone therapy.

title: The ideal time to start HRT
content: Ideally around menopause. Starting HRT within the first 10 years of cessation of periods. “There is no increased risk if a woman begins HRT at the time of menopause. . .with no preexisting cardiac vascular disease.” “If you take a woman entering the normal, perimenopausal to menopausal state, and she has no preexisting cardiovascular disease. . .the data make it pretty clear there’s no increase in her risk of cardiovascular disease ongoing.”

title: Is it safe for older women to receive HRT?
content: However, that doesn’t mean that older women must never take it. In fact, that increased risk of cardiovascular events is seen generally only during the first year that a woman starts hormones. Hypothetical case: 60 year old women. She went into menopause at 50, so she has a window now that is 10 years. There is zero evidence that she has existing cardiovascular disease. She begins hormone replacement therapy. ⇒ How clear are the data that she is also not increasing her risk of cardiovascular disease? Yes, “she’s probably okay”. “But… we are not here trying to increase sales of hormones”. “What we want to do is empower women so that they are not to be given some curt answer when they ask about [their doctor] about it. This is a legitimate course of action to follow, but with and after a discussion with your physician.”

title: Defining the risks
content: Another hypothetical case study: A woman who has never been on hormones more than 10 years out of menopause with some preexisting clinical or subclinical atherosclerosis. ⇒ Is her risk only one year after starting therapy and then it returns to baseline? Her risk is highest during that first year. And then it diminishes and diminishes and diminishes. So, if during the first year an event doesn’t occur, the likelihood is they will be well and won’t have one of these events later on.

title: Papers showing HRT is beneficial for heart disease
content: Estrogen and coronary heart disease in women. 1991 report that estrogen can help reduce the incidence of heart disease.

title: Hip Fractures and Osteoporosis
content: As many women in the United States will die each year of a hip fracture as the number who will die of breast cancer. Approximately 21% of women who fracture their hip will die within a year of the hip fracture. Looking at bone mineral density is the way we currently test for osteoporosis. However, bone mineral density a poor substitute but it’s the best we have. The true test is how much a bone can be flexed before it snaps. Calcium and vitamin D help mostly with the outer shell of the bone. But it is the internal girder network of the bone which is important. In a postmenopausal women who is not on estrogen, calcium and vitamin D have no protective effect against hip fracture. Bisphosphonates do help prevent hip fracture almost as well as estrogen does. However, if you take them for longer than five years, you have an increased risk of fractures within the femoral shaft. Estrogen will decrease the risk of osteoporotic hip fracture by up to 50%. Better than any treatment available over the long term.

title: Colon Cancer
content: Colon cancer is more lethal than breast cancer. A number of significant studies have shown that HRT does indeed reduce the risk of colon cancer. Estrogen protects against the growth of cancerous cells in the colon. Nurses’ Health Study showed a 20-25% decreased risk of colon cancer among women taking estrogen. At the beginning with the WHI, they were claiming that estrogen reduced longevity and increased women’s mortality from all causes over the years. It was quite an exaggerated claim and over the years they have been walking back from that one.

title: Diabetes
content: Diabetes seems to decrease when taking estrogen. The numbers suggested it. That’s all. I would like to see many more studies before we reach that conclusion.

title: Downsides of HRT
content: The risk of pulmonary embolism resulting from a venous thromboembolism is small. With a blood clot in a vein in part of the body (the leg, for example) it is usually not very serious unless a piece of the clot breaks off, and goes to the lung. A pulmonary embolism can be fatal. The incidence is of this small, however… Cholecystectomy, removing a gallbladder among women who are on hormones, is a not infrequently reported finding and has to be considered.

title: Approaching Your Doctor About HRT
content: Avrum advises that if the patient has a condition or is taking something that can predispose to that kind of clot, it must be a consideration before somebody starts on hormones.

title: HRT and Disease
content: HRT seems to have an impact on 80-85% of the diseases that lead to death in women including, but not limited to: Cancer, Atherosclerosis (all of the cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases), Alzheimer’s disease, and Bone fractures. There won’t be anything as big as the women’s health initiative (complex, costly, and “already done”).

title: Estriol and Testosterone
content: We don’t have large scale studies on estriol, so Avrum advises to be cautious. Testosterone has been associated with the development of breast cancer. It can show some stimulation of growth of breast cancer in culture, and that too has to be looked at very carefully.

title: Research on HRT
content: The cost and complexity of repeating a study of the magnitude of the WHI is standing in the way. Carol argues that observational studies can be useful in this field. We are lulled into a false sense of confidence with randomized control trials, and yet virtually all of them have some measure of what’s called performance bias… “just because something is a randomized control trial, doesn’t mean it is free of bias”.

title: Bad Science in Epidemiology
content: The demands on researchers to publish or perish has meant a proliferation of badly analyzed studies. So this is where you’re an epidemiologist, you’ve got thousands and thousands of people in your sample, and you don’t find what you thought you would find. So instead of saying, ‘we find no connection between these two things’, they then engage in these statistical practices that are no-nos for any statistician or scientist to do. Yet the results find homes in medical journals.

title: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia
content: This used to be one of the hardest malignancies to treat. About 15 years ago, several investigators found that the problem is not that these terrible looking cells are multiplying too quickly, it’s that these cells are facing a maturation arrest. In the case of acute promyeloblastic leukemia, there’s a form of vitamin A called trans retinoic acid that can given to the patient as a treatment. This treatment can remove the maturation arrest, and the abnormal leukemic cells proceed through normal maturation and the disease disappears and the patient is better.

title: Looking at Stromal Cells
content: Investigators are starting to look at stromal cells. Up until recently, we have focused almost exclusively on the actual cell that has undergone the genetic alteration to render it a cancerous. But the stromal cell that surrounds it, the environment in which it lives in cellularly, is now where people are starting to realize there’s something there. Now how we target that for treatment becomes a second question.

title: Welcoming the Critics
content: “We welcome the criticism and the discussion. And rather than make enemies, we welcome critics, and that way we will all learn. We don’t claim to have the final answer, but we think that this book [Estrogen Matters] represents an important step forward in empowering women and helping them live longer and live better.”

title: Racial Differences in Benefits and Risks with HRT
content: When we talk about race, we know that there are different racial predispositions to breast cancer. Has anything come out of all of the reevaluations of the data that would suggest one way or another that Caucasian, African-American, Hispanic, Asian women might actually benefit or be harmed differentially from hormones? “To the best of my knowledge, no” says Avrum. Although, the overwhelming majority of studies are looking at caucasians. That said, national menopause societies in every country from India and African nations and South America and Canada and others have all endorsed the beneficial use of HRT for women.

title: Hormone therapy: why everything you thought you knew about HRT is wrong
content: The London Times put out a favorable review of the book: Hormone therapy: why everything you thought you knew about HRT is wrong by Anna Maxted

title: Why you should read Estrogen Matters
content: Peter is adamant, “I think everybody should make the effort to read this book and should actually follow up in the references. . . because what you did nicely is you laid out the time course of the literature of the studies, and I think that’s an important exercise.” Avrum: “Our goal was to make the book readable enough for lay readers. Certainly of course for women personally concerned about this issue so that they will understand what the evidence shows without having to read every study at hand if they don’t want to.” Carol: “So our goal was to make it readable for general readers, but also to provide the sources and information for those who want to know in more detail what the science shows.”

title: HRT after a diagnosis of breast cancer
content: Still an open question without an obvious conclusion. However, some evidence suggesting it might not be harmful, and could be beneficial: For example, getting pregnant after having a diagnosis of breast cancer does not compromise the prognosis. There are approximately 15 studies on the subject and only 1 of them showed an increase in breast cancer risk. Avrum did a study administering HRT to his patients who had had breast cancer. Over 14 years showed no increased risks of local recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, or distant recurrence among the women who took hormones, compared to the women who didn’t, when they were matched stage for stage. See chapter 6 of Estrogen Matters for more on this.
